title: Big Bang Theory cast members took pay cuts for fairer salaries but Friends led the way for equal pay
text:
Big Bang Theory cast members took pay cuts for fairer salaries but Friends led the way for equal pay Friends negotiated equal salaries in 2002 Share Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The stars of The Big Bang Theory made headlines yesterday when it was revealed the show's biggest stars kindly took pay cuts so two supporting actors could get more money. 
But they're not the first sitcom actors to do this - the stars of Friends led the way for equal salaries 15 years ago. 
Back in 2002 the stars of Friends - Jennifer Aniston, Matt LeBlanc, Courteney Cox, Lisa Kudrow, David Schwimmer and Matthew Perry - famously settled for $1 million each an episode. 
But they didn't always get equal pay. The Friends cast negotiated for equal pay (Photo: Reuters) 
When Friends started it was an ensemble show so the six main stars were paid an equal $22,500 an episode. 
Then as the show became a hit and Rachel and Ross's will-they-won't-they relationship became a crucial plot - Aniston and Schwimmer began to earn more. 
But the cast - who also formed a strong bond in real life - didn't like the inequality in their pay. 
So when it came to negotiating salaries for series three - they negotiated not as individual actors but as an ensemble, led by Schwimmer and Kudrow, according to Entertainment Weekly . David Schwimmer as Ross Geller, Jennifer Aniston as Rachel Green (Photo: NBCUniversal) 
To achieve bigger salaries for the rest of the cast, Aniston and Schwimmer's salaries were reduced so the others' pay could go up. 
They bagged $75,000 each an episode for season three rising to $1 million by seasons nine and 10. 
The Friends actors also earn royalties from syndication rights and each cast member still gets $20 million a year from syndication, according to USA Today . The stars were paid $1million an episode by the last series (Photo: Wenn) 
Big Bang's five original cast members on the show - Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, Kaley Cuoco, Kunal Nayyar and Simon Helberg - now earn around $1million per episode. 
And with negotiations for the final two seasons of Big Bang drawing to a close, reps Melissa Rauch and Mayim Bialik are said to be pressing for the studio to add some more coin to their paychecks as well, reports Variety. 
Bialik and Rauch both joined the show in season three and have earned significantly less than their co-stars. The Big Bang Theory stars are in similar negotiations over pay (Photo: Warner Bros) 
Both actresses are in the $200,000 per episode range this season, the show's 10th, compared to the $1million per episode for the original five. 
In the renewal talks that began late last year, the original cast members agreed to take a $100,000 cut in salary for the prospective 11th and 12th seasons to free up $500,000 to fund raises for Bialik and Rauch. 
If Bialik and Rauch split the $500,000 from their co-stars, both would rise to nearly $450,000 an episode, or more than $21 million for the two-year, 48-episode deal. The three girls currently earn different salaries (Photo: Channel 4) Bernadette has become a crucial character (Photo: Channel 4) 
Bialik's Amy Farrah Fowler is the girlfriend of Parsons' Sheldon Cooper, a relationship that has added emotional depth to the show. 
Rauch's Bernadette Rostenkowski had a baby earlier this season with Helberg's Howard Wolowitz's character, which provided another source of highly rated episodes. Bialik has nabbed four consecutive supporting actress Emmy noms from 2012-15. Amy is Sheldon's girlfriend (Photo: Channel 4) 
In the last Big Bang contract renewal cycle, Helberg and Nayyar secured raises that eventually brought them to seven-figure parity (as of this current season) with Parsons, Galecki and Cuoco. 
But the timing for Bialik and Rauch to reach the high six-figure threshold is not as optimum as it was three years ago for Helberg and Nayyar. 
The show has grossed over $1 billion in syndication for Warner Bros. Like us on Facebook
